article.title: Getting Started with the Netspective Enterprise Frameworks (NEF)
article.para: The quickest way to evaluate the NEF is to view all the documentation online and follow along with the online versions of the applications created in the tutorials. The main advantages of this method are simplicity and speed. Since all you need is a web browser, you can start learning about NEF immediately. You will also be introduced to NEF's built-in remote development and team programming capabilities. The disadvantage is that you will not have the ability to dabble in or change the application code yourself.

The recommended method of evaluating NEF is to download sample applications and install them in your own application server. The main advantage of using this method is that you will get a good hands-on look at NEF and, by the time you are through with the documentation and tutorials, you will be well on your way to developing your own applications using NEF. The only disadvantage is that you’ll need to download and install a Java Developer’s Kit (JDK), an application server, and one or more NEF sample applications on your own server.

note.para: Each of the downloadable sample applications are provided as app-server-independent .war files. Each sample app's .war file includes all of the NEF binary files, resources, and everything you need to use NEF. Once you have downloaded any .war file, you have everything you need to start modifying and adding to the app.

section.title: Using the Netspective Enterprise Sampler to Sample the NEF Online
section.para: The Enterprise Sampler application (available at http://sampler.netspective.com or http://localhost:8080/nefs-sampler if you installed the sampler application in your own app server) is an NEF application that helps you navigate your way through all the NEF sample applications, test beds, and starter projects. The Sampler may also be used to obtain both the latest and archived releases of the Frameworks.

section.title: Viewing Source Code in a Browser
section.para: The Netspective administration console, called the Enterprise Console, provides a complete file browser with color syntax highlighting for XML, JSP, Java, JavaScript, and SQL files – this file browser allows you to review source code for sample applications at http://sampler.netspective.com or locally if you downloaded the sample applications.

The Enterprise Console is a Sparx Servlet that provides a browser-based administrative interface to all of the dynamic components and objects that NEF produces. The Enterprise Console is automatically available to all NEF-based applications during development and each NEF application has a private instance of the Console available at http://[server]/[appName]/console. When you log into the Console for Application X (.../appX/console) versus Y (.../appY/console) you will only see components for the appropriate application. The Console's default user name is 'console' and the default password is 'console'. Unless otherwise specified, that is the user name and password combination you should use if the Console prompts you to login.

Once you have logged into the Console for any particular application, all of the source files and folders are available for viewing. Simply click on the Project tab and then click Project Folders to view all of the folders contained in the application and Project Files to navigate all the directories and look at the project files. The first time you enter the Project Files section, you should see a list of all the directories that exist in the application’s root directory. You can click on any directory to navigate to it and view the list of files and sub-directories inside it.
If you click on any XML, JSP or Java source file, you should also be able to see the source for those files directly from the browser.

section.title: Using your own App Server to Sample the NEF on your Workstation
section.para: In order to sample the true power of the NEF, you should try the samples on your own workstation or server. This section describes the prerequisites you need to sample NEF locally:

listitem.para: A Servlet Container (application server) supporting the Servlet 2.2 or higher specification

section.title: Make sure you have a Java Developer's Kit (JDK)
section.para: Since NEF is comprised of Java libraries, a fundamental requirement to develop applications with it is a Java SDK (the full SDK is required, the JRE will not be enough). You can obtain Sun’s official Java SDK from its Java web site at http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.4/download.html. This is a link to the Java 1.4 SDK but Java 1.2 and 1.3 will also work.

section.title: Make sure you have an Application Server (Servlet Container)
section.para: Since Sparx works with standard J2EE application servers, a Servlet container is required if you're going to use Sparx. Both Axiom and Commons work in web-based or non-web-based applications but Sparx is a web application development library so an application server with a Servlet 2.2 or better container is necessary. Sparx-based applications have been tested on the following application servers:

listitem.para: Caucho Resin (free for development, commercial license required for deployment)

note.para: We recommend the Caucho Resin application server if you're not familiar with other Servlet containers or if you're new to Java/J2EE application servers. It's an easy to install, easy to use, and fast Servlet container with advanced features that rival other more expensive application servers such as WebLogic and WebSphere. Resin is free for development use but requires a paid license before putting your application into production use. Rest assured though that all Sparx-based applications you write, even on Resin, will remain app-server neutral.

section.title: Use an Integrated Development Environment (IDE)
section.para: You can also optionally install a Java integrated development environment (IDE) for developing NEF applications. The Netspective Frameworks do not require any particular Java IDE and if you prefer to use simple text editors like vi, emacs, or TextPad those will do just as well. We recommend the free Eclipse IDE or very affordable and useful JetBrain’s IDEA for those who are not already familiar with other IDEs.

section.title: Evaluating NEF Using the Sample Applications
section.para:
To keep things simple, there's no special "evaluation kit" for NEF -- instead you just download a sample application from http://sampler.netspective.com, drop it into your favorite Servlet container (application server) and you'll be ready for the evaluation. Each of the sample applications are provided as app-server-independent .war files and each sample app's .war file includes all of the NEF binary files, resources, etc. you need to use NEF. Once you have downloaded any .war file, you have everything you need to start modifying and adding to the app. The typical procedure is:
Download and install an application server (Servlet container).
Go to http://sampler.netspective.com and pick any application you're interested in evaluating.
Download the .war file and place it into the app server's web applications root.
Start (or restart) the application server.
Use your browser to point to http://localhost:port/appName to run the application or http://localhost:port/appName/console to run the application's Console servlet.

section.title: Evaluating NEF Sample Applications on Caucho Resin
section.para: This section provides an overview of how to obtain, install, and start the Caucho Resin application server and the Hello Forms sample application. See the Resin QuickStart document for the most up-to-date information.

listitem.para: Install JDK 1.3 or late if you're using Resin 2.1 or above. JDK 1.4 or later if you're using Resin 3.0 or above. On Unix, set the JAVA_HOME variable or link /usr/java to the Java home. On Windows, check to make sure the JDK installation set JAVA_HOME correctly.
Download the latest Resin release (something like resin-x.y.z.zip, e.g. resin-3.0.4.zip or resin-3.0.4.tar.gz).
Uncompress (unzip/untar) the package into C:\resin-x.y.z, e.g. C:\resin-3.0.4, or other directory.
Click here to download the Hello Forms sample application and save it in c:\resin-x.y.z\webapps.
Start resin-x.y.z/bin/httpd.sh on Unix or resin-x.y.z/bin/httpd.exe on Win32. This will start up a local web server and the application server at the same time.

Browse http://localhost:8080 to make sure Resin is working properly. If you do not see the Resin welcome page, please see the Resin Installation document for appropriate help. If Resin is not working properly, Sparx will not be able to run either.
Browse http://localhost:8080/nefs-sample-hello-forms to run the application or http://localhost:8080/nefs-sample-hello-forms/console to run the Hello Forms Console servlet.
